comments.content:
Thanks kris!   
FYI, there's an illustration missing - it should be added by the end of the day.   
   
(You see, I had to post _something_ quickly, otherwise John's parenthetical prediction in his opening sentence would have been wrong. :-)   
   
hhp

_"Loved the interview, Hrant! THX for letting us peek through the skylight in yo' head. It confirmed some suspicions of mine"_   
   
Is that a nice way of saying that Hrant has a big hole in his head?..... ;?)   
   
Is that a recent photo of you Hrant that you use when posting?   
   
gln

That photo is very old - I was half the age. But after an eleven-year absence I do have that goatee back again, so the photo actually looks more like me now than it did for a long while!   
   
hhp

Hrant, I enjoyed the interview, thanks for sharing your thinking and your time!   
   
Jon

Hi Hrant,   
Thanks for the interview. Your ideas are very crispy and that's nice to read.   
   
Nicolien

i really like the line:   
   
'I really love hounds, they�re the newspaper fonts of the dog world.'

question is: what are hounds of the newspaper font world?   
   
surely not baskerville ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20051123012311im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)

Great interview. I haven't been a part of typophile that long at all, but it didn't take more than a few first hours on these pages to know that you're one of the greats.   
   
Thanks for all the insights!

\> what are hounds of the newspaper font world?   
   
It's not a news face, but I've always seen Quadraat as a bloodhound. Times is a bit self-conscious, so maybe an Ibizan (although it's very hard picturing Morison in a trance club): [http://www.akc.org/breeds/recbreeds/ibizan.cfm](http://web.archive.org/web/20051123012311/http:/www.akc.org/breeds/recbreeds/ibizan.cfm)   
   
Baskerville? Some kind of terrier - maybe an Airedale.   
   
hhp

**JC: You�re a prolific contributor to the type lists and forums. How do you balance your writing with your type design � and oh yeah � with your day job and family?**    
   
_HHP: I think the worst thing I could do to anybody who might actually be interested in this question would be to truncate their stimulating guesswork. An exposition of the reality � in fact merely my perception of such � would certainly be less motivational than what the average imagination can create._    
   
Oh, my gosh. That definitely wins the Donald Rumsfeld Award for Creative Obsfucation and Non-Informative Response. [grin]   
   
Nice work, both Jon & Hrant.

Rummy is a hack. He needs to read some Disraeli.   
   
hhp

In that case, how do you prounce   
your name?

In which case?   
Usually it's pronounced huh-RUNT, the second part just like the English word of that spelling (soft "r", "uh" not "oo"). In Eastern Armenian the ending is a "d". In French it sounds like a pig being run over.   
   
hhp
Aw man! I think that the pronunciation of "Hrant" was a bigger mystery than what you do with your free time! :\*) (my emoticon has a bloody nose, I think)

\>Rummy is a hack. He needs to read some Disraeli.   
   
Hm? I've always admired Disraeli from afar. Any recommendations?

No idea. I mostly know him from reputation. Seems like a weasel to me, but you gotta respect his golden tongue. Except nobody can beat William Buckley: he can make perfect sense yet prevent 95% of people from understanding him.   
   
hhp

_Seems like a weasel to me, but you gotta respect his golden tongue._   
   
A contrast perfectly captured in the title of Jean Negulesco's biographical film, starring a young John Gielgud as Disraeli: _The Mudlark_
